video.title: Call of Duty: Black Ops 4 (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text:
I know Call of Duty and I have had our ups
and downs - well, had our downs and our downs,

and more downs and just when we thought we
couldn&#39;t go any further down we broke new

ground and discovered a sealed-off basement
where a family of horny pigs were passing

around the corpse of Modern Warfare 1, but
when I saw that Cod Blops 4 was coming out,
I felt renewed vigour.

After having to plough through so many RPGs
and open worlds in very limited time I was

in the right mood for a nice straightforward
four hour story campaign, and hell, as a white

person it&#39;ll be nice see the genetic superiority
of my race being confirmed for a little while.

That was when Cod Blops 4 laid its knob across
my porridge for the first time - no single
player campaign.

Well, Activision, as Milorad Petrovic said
in response to the invasion of Yugoslavia,
the fuck?
We thought you&#39;d be pleased, Yahtz.

Every story campaign of every CoD game you&#39;ve
played in years you call racist and overblown

and taken straight from what insecure NRA
members see when they close their eyes and
touch themselves.

At least we didn&#39;t hire Kit Harington this
time.

Granted, but having removed the single player
are you going to charge less for the game?

&quot;Oh ho ho, Yahtzee, I can see why people say
you&#39;re a funny guy.&quot;
130 bucks, the deluxe version costs.

As the water treatment engineer said of his
favourite outflow pipe, that&#39;s taking a lot
of piss.

I can see why it&#39;s not on Steam, Steam has
user reviews.

There&#39;d be a big fat &quot;mostly negative&quot; next
to the name before you can say Eric Prince.

Still, saying the game has no single player
content would doubtless annoy a few marketing
types.
&quot;Of course there&#39;s single player content!&quot;
They would say.

&quot;You can play the tutorial missions as many
times as you like!&quot;

There are ten playable characters and a little
tutorial for each, and they&#39;re worth going

through just because the person narrating
them is the most insecure man in the universe,
and for Call of Duty that&#39;s saying something.

&quot;Yeah, press that grenade key, knock knock,
mother fuckers, it&#39;s your birthday and the

party clown&#39;s here, you&#39;re a stone cold brass
balled killer and you&#39;re gonna have their

ass for supper, I&#39;d like to put your penis
in my mouth - I MEAN take you to a steak restaurant

and barbecue an entire cow using nothing but
the pressure cooker effect of my giant balls.&quot;
He&#39;s great.

It&#39;s like listening to Jeremy Clarkson&#39;s stream
of consciousness while he&#39;s using the communal
shower at the YMCA.

And by doing these missions you also unlock
the story.
For the story had to be somewhere.

Without story there&#39;s no context and even
a multiplayer game needs context.
Shut up, yes it does.

If you don&#39;t need context there are literally
hundreds of ways you could scratch your itch

of wanting to shoot human shaped things with
a gun (although maybe stick to video games
if you&#39;re planning to do it more than once.)

Story cutscenes are gradually unlocked as
you complete the character tutorials, so here&#39;s
the story as I understood it.

Very rich white lady is sad because her sister
died in a gun battle and in response gathers

ten elite mercenaries from around the world
so that they can gun battle.
In aid of... something.

She says something about ending war, but I
don&#39;t think you do that with gun battles.

That&#39;s like enlisting major game publishers
in a campaign for reasonably priced entertainment.

Then she betrays the mercenaries for some
reason, and that&#39;s your lot.

For the reasons described above, the ten mercenaries
will now gun battle an infinite number of

clones of each other in various enclosed industrial
environments for the rest of time.

Ooh, maybe they&#39;re all dead and in purgatory,
Yahtz.
Oh shut up viewer, you always say that.

Just because Lost confirmed it you think you
know everything now.

There&#39;s an air of desperation about Cod Blops
4.

If it had a subtitle - well, a sub-subtitle
- it&#39;d be &quot;What the fuck do you people want?&quot;

It&#39;s basically a collection of gameplay modes
that several phenomenally popular other games
have all done before and less blandly.

Its challenge is not so much finding an audience
as it is luring that audience away from the
games it already has.

The ten playable characters in the I hesitate
to call it &#39;main&#39; multiplayer mode smacks

of Overwatch-style hero shooters, but the
characters just aren&#39;t distinct enough.

It takes more than different hairdoes and
a greater variety of accents than a French
punctuation manual.

They&#39;re all basically the same size and speed
and their unique weapons and abilities take

time to warm up so most of the time is spent
running around blasting assault rifles at

each other, and again there are plenty of
games where you can do that, some of which

don&#39;t run like complete garbage on graphics
cards more than six months old.
And then of course there&#39;s the PUBG mode.
&quot;We&#39;d prefer you call it Blackout mode, Yahtz.&quot;

Well that&#39;s very adorable of you but it&#39;ll
take more than terminology to disguise the
fact that it&#39;s just PUBG.

I suppose the lesson that Fortnite taught
us was that PUBG&#39;s audience is completely

up for grabs to anyone who can rip off PUBG
without being quite so buggy and awful, but

there&#39;s something particularly cynical about
a big triple-A franchise doing it, presumably

hoping a cozy and familiar name on the top
will draw them in, like a supermarket own
brand packet of fish fingers.

And the third gameplay mode is that co-op
zombies thing that&#39;s been hanging around Call

of Duty for years now like a friendzoned nice
guy constantly thinking they must be one more

badmouthed boyfriend away from getting some
of that.

Now, as you all know not being into this whole
&quot;human society&quot; thing I&#39;m not big on online

multiplayer and as such don&#39;t have much constructive
criticism for how the game actually plays.

When I joined public matches I&#39;d do a quick
poll of the other players and ask them for

one small change they&#39;d suggest to balance
the game, and Treyarch will be pleased to

know that I now have about 85,000 suggestions
for very simple changes, and they might also

be interested to hear that they&#39;re all a bunch
of cucks.

However there is one criticism I can make
with complete confidence, and that&#39;s that
the entire menu interface is complete dogshit.

You wouldn&#39;t think this would be difficult
- New Game, Options, Quit - especially not

when there&#39;s like a hundred guys working on
it.
But that&#39;s it, isn&#39;t it.

Boiling an egg is easy, but if you&#39;ve got
a hundred guys in your kitchen trying to boil

one egg you won&#39;t achieve much beyond violating
the fire code.

You have to wade through screen after screen
of shitty rectangles to do anything.

I was trying to read all the dossiers for
the ten characters &#39;cos god knows I wasn&#39;t

getting much context from playing as the fuckers,
but I had to go three screens deep and back

just to switch characters and the text fucks
up in every way it is possible to fuck up
a simple text box.

There&#39;s more than enough space to display
all the text at once but they put it in a

tiny box anyway and autoscroll it, and when
it reaches the bottom, if you&#39;re not finished
reading, fuck you, back to the top.

It&#39;s like trying to read the side of a truck
as it rolls down a hill into a burning slurry
pit.

And I&#39;m harping on it because it reflects
the complacency and utter contempt for the

audience with which this game thinks it can
do nothing but present a box of scraps it

ripped off better games and charge a hundred
bucks.

I suppose the question is, would you prefer
to plan a day out to do one specific thing,

like scuba diving or seal clubbing, or go
to Disneyland and do four or five shallow

imitations of interesting things, all with
this constant nagging sense that someone&#39;s
trying to steal all your money
and children.
